CURRENT_STATUS:
Council’s resolution requiring Austin Energy to reach 90% of the eligible
low-income customers (estimated to be up to 93,000 customers) resulted in
setting three enrollment milestones through 2025, which will culminate in Austin
Energy reaching the established goal: • 46% of eligible customers enrolled by
June 2023: 42,780 households (exceeded) • 72% of eligible customers enrolled by
June 2024: 66,690 households (exceeded) • 90% of eligible customers enrolled by
June 2025: 83,700 households To meet these goals, Austin Energy completed a
process to add new programs to qualify customers for CAP discounts, including

expansion measures have, thus far, exceeded the enrollment milestone goals,

measures to manage the program while ensuring eligible individuals receive
benefits quickly and efficiently. Regular data reviews and cross-checks against
multiple data sources are part of our analysis. Our plan manages risk well
within acceptable industry standards for similar programs

CURRENT_STATUS:
City‐ owned facilities are directed to display the Progress Pride Flag
throughout the month of June each year. The Building Services Department (BSD)
recognizes there are a variety of facilities owned by the City. As such, this
information will apply to the public-facing facilities with a flagpole and/or a
public lobby. Department Directors shall at a minimum display the Pride Flag at
their department headquarters buildings and use discretion in determining the
appropriate display of the Pride flag at other locations in alignment with the
resolution. Flags may be displayed rather than flown in cases where a flagpole
is unavailable. Displays may include being hung against a wall or in the air of
an atrium. Displays should be in an area where a member of the public could
reasonably view the flag and in alignment with established flag guidance and
norms. For more information on flag etiquette, you can review statutory laws
U.S. Code Section 7 and Texas Government Code Title 11. Council’s direction in
the resolution is for departments to use the Progress Pride flag, which is
distinct from the rainbow flag

Approve a resolution to establish Austin as a recognized soccer city and
directing the City Manager to analyze challenges and needs in soccer field
development and soccer programming and to provide recommendations.
CURRENT_STATUS:
Inventory of Public Land and Existing Soccer Programming The resolution directed
the City Manager to create an inventory of the public lands owned by the City,
County, and school districts that are used or could be utilized to play soccer.
Additionally, the resolution directed the City Manager to provide an inventory
of existing soccer programming. The Austin Parks and Recreation Department
(PARD) updated the Athletics Program’s Soccer webpage to include: •
Comprehensive information on all publicly available soccer fields and mini
pitches; • An interactive map of Austin’s public soccer fields, mini pitches,
and multi-purpose fields; • Existing soccer programming, soccer leagues,
community programs, and youth soccer programs to include collaborations between
the City of Austin, Austin Independent School District (AISD), and many soccer
organizations that provide community soccer programs and leagues on public
parkland; and • Other soccer-related information. Attached is an inventory of
undeveloped parkland with high level criteria indicating the land may be
suitable for soccer based on the following factors: • Minimum of three (3)
acres, • Slopes of less than 10 percent, and • Tree canopy coverage of less than
50 percent Also included is an inventory of AISD schools, (middle and high
schools) where soccer is already taking place on their multi-purpose fields. A
more detailed inventory would require additional external resources to conduct a
complete assessment of our fields and indicate what level of play would be
recommended. Financial Assistance The resolution directed the City Manager to
expand financial assistance for youth programs to increase program
participation, including outreach efforts to promote the program and ways for
residents to donate to the PARD Financial Aid Program. Residents can participate
in youth soccer leagues through PARD recreation centers. PARD currently provides
financial assistance to youth who live within Austin city limits and are
income-eligible to receive free/reduced school lunches and/or individuals 18 to
22 years of age who receive special education services in school. This aid
covers fifty percent of registration fees for PARD programs and services.
Applications are available on PARD’s Financial Aid webpage in six languages.
Additionally, an emerging Support Austin Parks webpage provides information
about how residents can donate to the PARD Financial Aid Program. Assessment of
Programming Needs and Park Vision Plans The resolution directed the City Manager
to provide an assessment of soccer fields and programming needs based on the
size and population of the City, the number of existing soccer leagues, and
community, and youth soccer programs. The assessment should include
recommendations to help address the existing need for soccer fields and soccer
programming. PARD utilizes data from the National Recreation and Park
Association (NRPA), a national not-for-profit organization focused on utilizing
parks and recreation to build strong, vibrant and resilient communities in
reviewing our level of service as compared to other cities based on size and
population. The NRPA represents the industry standard that PARD looks to for
benchmarking and manages the Certified Parks and Recreation Agency certification
which PARD is certified under. The 2024 NRPA Agency Performance Review does not
provide specific metrics for soccer fields and programming needs based on size
and population. Instead, it provides metrics based on a “typical” agency (median
of data collected). The breakdown of the most common responses for a population
of jurisdiction over 250,000 is one rectangular field for every 14,238
residents. Based on Austin’s current population of 987,567, NRPA metric would
recommend that Austin have at least 69 rectangular fields. Austin currently
exceeds that number, with parkland currently providing 106 field locations that
are suitable for soccer play and open to the public, of which there are 76
multi-field spaces for informal play, 26 dedicated soccer fields, and 4 mini
pitch locations. PARD is adding lighting to existing soccer fields at Dove
Springs District Park to create more playing time. There is also a plan to add a
multi-purpose field at Springfield Pocket Park along William Cannon but funding
has not yet been identified. Additionally, this resolution directed the City
Manager to provide an assessment of all City of Austin Park Vision Plans to
identify opportunities for soccer field development for all levels of play. City
of Austin Park Vision Plans are developed through an extensive community
engagement process and are used to prioritize park development. While the
national vision planning model doesn’t identify soccer as a specific park use,
PARD has received community feedback to incorporate this into Austin vision
plans.. These uses are often labeled “open play” or “multi-use fields” meaning
areas in the park that can be used for soccer or other field sports/activities.
PARD purchased the Walnut Creek Sports Complex (228 acres located along Johnny
Morris Road in northeast Austin), specially to develop sports fields to promote
organized play such as softball, baseball, soccer fields, and tennis courts.
This complex has not yet been developed. A Request For Information (RFI) process
was completed to find a partner for the development of the complex through a
public-private collaboration. Unfortunately, we were unable yield any results.
This facility remains in the PARD inventory and could be developed in the future
if the significant funding required becomes available. Collaboration This
resolution directed the City Manager to seek public and private partnerships to
expand public access to soccer facilities and programs and to attract new soccer
sporting events to the City, including considering establishing an interest
group coalition with appropriate stakeholder organizations. PARD has partnered
with 4 ATX Foundation, a non-profit arm of Austin FC to build public use mini
pitch courts on underutilized tennis courts at parks to include: Wooldridge
School Park, Dove Springs District Park, and Civitan Neighborhood Park. The City
of Austin celebrated the recent formation of the Verde Pitch Alliance (VPA) and
its aim to bring more free and public soccer spaces to Central Texas to increase
the number of fields and parks that can be utilized to play soccer at all levels
of play, including additional mini-pitches and fields. This coalition includes
Street Soccer USA, Austin Parks Foundation, Soccer Assist, Austin FC, and 4ATX
Foundation. PARD has organized initial discussions between VPA’s built
environment soccer partners with City of Austin representatives, including
representatives from Watershed Protection, Development Services, and Parks and
Recreation’s landscape architecture team. The aim of these initial discussions
is to explore processes and strategies to more easily facilitate the development
of these facilities with support from city agencies. In 2021, PARD issued a
Request for Interest to gauge the private sector’s interest in investing in
parkland development. The RFI received little interest due to expensive upfront
infrastructure costs. In January of 2024, PARD partnered with Austin Sports
Commission to hire The Sports Facilities Companies to develop a marketing
opportunity analysis and detailed financial forecast related to the future
development of Walnut Creek Sports Complex. The final report has not been
completed, but when it is it will provide guidance on the level of public
investment needed to attract potential interest in further development.
Additionally, this resolution directed the City Manager to foster collaboration
between the City, County, school districts, soccer leagues and organizations in
Austin. Existing soccer programming, soccer leagues, community programs, and
youth soccer programs that are provided on public parkland include
collaborations between the City of Austin, Austin Independent School District
(AISD), and many soccer organizations. It is widely recognized that public land
owned and managed by the County, City or School District is currently used for
informal soccer play. In 2025, Travis County initiated development of its
10-year Long Range Plan, and our understanding is that their focus will be on
developing more nature-based parks rather than field-based sports facilities.
Recommendations This resolution directed the City Manager to review whether the
recommendations to address the identified challenges, including park maintenance
and soccer field development, could be funded through general fund expenditures
and/or bond instruments to be approved at a future election. PARD has identified
future opportunities to grow the sport, but these require additional resources
for development. The traditional ways PARD has funded these improvements have
been through Park Bonds, parkland dedication funds, grants and through
partnerships. Once development dollars are secured, there may be impacts to the
General Fund that include maintenance of the fields, as well as utility
expenses.

at the APL.

Approve a resolution directing the City Manager to prepare City Code amendments
that will prohibit the sale of e-cigarettes, vapes, and synthetic nicotine
products within 1,000 feet of a school or daycare; initiating amendments to City
Code Title 25 (Land Development) to the extent necessary to carry out the goal
of the resolution; and requesting a report and stakeholder engagement on any
proposed ordinances prepared in response to the resolution.
CURRENT_STATUS:
APH is leading a multi-department research study in to peer-City research f
synthetic nicotine products and e-cigarettes of any kind regulations. The
workgroup is determining the best approach given Texas law and the intention of
the resolution to regulate all retail environments near schools and daycares,
and not just vape and tobacco shops. Staff have conducted preliminary
stakeholder meetings with four (4) public health organizations, the City of San
Antonio, and attended three (3) community meetings for school personnel, daycare
personnel, and youth advocates. Next steps include engaging with convenience and
vape and tobacco shop owners and managers, as well as school administrators,
district personnel, and day care owners. Staff will prepare a report summarizing
engagement efforts. Feedback gathered during the engagement process will inform
development of a draft ordinance.

CURRENT_STATUS:

Districts and Amending Density Bonus 90 and Vertical Mixed Use.

CURRENT_STATUS:
Childcare Fee Waiver Program Update In May 2025, the Economic Development
Department (EDD) provided the Economic Opportunity Committee an update on the
childcare fee waiver program, outlining three new categories for waivers: (1)
Conditional Use Permits, (2) Expansion of High-Quality Childcare Programs, and
(3) Annual Fire Inspections for High-Quality Childcare Programs. At that
meeting, Mayor Pro Tem Fuentes expressed interest in expanding waivers to also
support construction of new childcare programs. During the budget process, EDD
staff collaborated with District 2 to advance Resolution 08132025-004, granting
authority to expand waivers to construction costs. Council approved the item,
and on August 26, 2025, EDD briefed District 2 on the recommendation to create a
new waiver category specifically for construction of new childcare programs.
District 2 staff supported the recommendation and will brief the Councilwoman
for feedback. EDD anticipates issuing a memo response to Mayor and Council by
Friday, September 19. In the meantime, staff are finalizing the program
application, updating the website, and preparing marketing materials, with full
program implementation planned for October.
